He was a master of reinvention, a chameleon who could change his colors to suit any situation, and I found myself wondering what lay beneath the surface of his carefully crafted facade. As I watched him move through the crowds, shaking hands and laughing with an ease that seemed almost supernatural, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of envy. Who was this man, and how had he managed to create such an aura of mystery and intrigue around himself? I knew that I had to find out more about him, to peel back the layers and uncover the truth that lay beneath. And so, I began to make discreet inquiries, asking questions and gathering information, determined to get to the bottom of the enigma that was Jay Gatsby. Little did I know, however, that the more I learned, the more I would become entangled in a web of secrets and lies that would change my life forever. The summer that followed was one of unrelenting heat and humidity, the kind of weather that makes the air feel heavy and oppressive, and it seemed to match the mood that was growing inside me. As I delved deeper into Gatsby's world, I found myself becoming increasingly disillusioned with the excesses of the wealthy elite, and the empty, superficial lives they led. And yet, despite my growing unease, I couldn't help but be drawn back to Gatsby, again and again, like a moth to a flame. There was something about him that was impossible to resist, a magnetism that seemed to pull me in, no matter how hard I tried to resist. I knew that I was playing with fire, but I couldn't help myself. I was addicted to the thrill of the unknown, and Gatsby was the ultimate enigma, a puzzle that I was determined to solve, no matter the cost.

Me da lo mismo, superado cierto punto, que la conducta se funde sobre piedra o sobre terreno pantanoso. Cuando volví del Este el otoño pasado, era consciente de que deseaba un mundo en uniforme militar, en una especie de vigilancia moral permanente; no deseaba más excursiones desenfrenadas y con derecho a privilegiados atisbos del corazón humano. La única excepción fue Gatsby, el hombre que da título a este libro: Gatsby, que representaba todo aquello por lo que siento auténtico desprecio. Si la personalidad es una serie ininterrumpida de gestos logrados, entonces había en Gatsby algo magnífico,
es_second_half: una exacerbada sensibilidad para las promesas de la vida, como si estuviera conectado a una de esas máquinas complejísimas que registran terremotos a quince mil kilómetros de distancia. Tal sensibilidad no tiene nada que ver con esa sensiblería fofa a la que dignificamos con el nombre de «temperamento creativo»: era un don extraordinario para la esperanza, una disponibilidad romántica como nunca he conocido en nadie y como probablemente no volveré a encontrar. No: Gatsby, al final, resultó ser como es debido. Fue lo que lo devoraba, el polvo viciado que dejaban sus sueños, lo que por un tiempo acabó con mi interés por los pesares inútiles y los entusiasmos insignificantes de los seres humanos.

en_first_half: And so it happened that on a warm windy evening I drove over to East Egg to see two old friends whom I scarcely knew at all. Their house was even more elaborate than I expected, a cheerful red-and-white Georgian Colonial mansion, overlooking the bay. The lawn started at the beach and ran towards the front door for a quarter of a mile, jumping over
en_second_half: sundials and brick walks and burning gardens—finally when it reached the house drifting up the side in bright vines as though from the momentum of its run. The front was broken by a line of French windows, glowing now with reflected gold and wide open to the warm windy afternoon, and Tom Buchanan in riding clothes was standing with his legs apart on the front porch.

en_results_raw: a succession of closely spaced dunes, and the front was broken by a line of French windows, glowing now with reflected gold and wide open to the warm windy afternoon, and Tom Buchanan in riding clothes was standing with his legs apart on the front porch. He had changed since his New Haven years. Now he was a sturdy, straw-haired man of thirty with a rather hard mouth and supercilious eyes given to staring at you in a way that suggested you'd just made a bet with him that he was going to pay off. "I was just going to have a swim," he said, and I was immediately struck by the hardening of his voice, its automatic assumption of the old established order. "Why don't you join me?" he suggested, and then added in a tone that was almost imperceptible, "if you care to." I was about to decline, but then I hesitated, and in that moment of hesitation, I felt a sudden sense of unease, a feeling that I was being drawn into something that I didn't fully understand. I looked around at the grandeur of the house, the manicured lawn, and the sparkling bay, and I felt a shiver run down my spine. Something was off, something that I couldn't quite put my finger on. But before I could respond, a voice called out from inside the house, a low, throaty voice that seemed to match the sultry tone of the evening. "Tom, darling, who's there?" it said, and Tom turned to answer, his eyes never leaving mine. "It's an old friend," he said, his voice dripping with an air of superiority. "Someone I knew at Yale." The voice from inside the house seemed to hesitate for a moment, and then it said, "Oh, how lovely. Do bring them in." And with that, Tom turned and walked back into the house, leaving me standing alone on the porch, feeling like an outsider looking in.

The nurse must have been puzzled by my reaction, but she just smiled and said, 'You're a lucky man, Mr. Buchanan.' I didn't feel lucky, though. I felt like I'd been robbed of something essential, something that could never be replaced. As I lay there, trying to process my emotions, I couldn't shake the feeling that my life was about to change in ways I couldn't even begin to imagine. And then, of course, there was the matter of Tom. Where was he, anyway? I knew he'd been drinking heavily the night before, but surely he wouldn't have just left me to face this moment alone. I felt a surge of anger at the thought, but it was quickly replaced by a sense of resignation. This was, after all, typical Tom behavior. I pushed the thought aside and focused on the tiny, swaddled form in the crib beside me. My daughter. I had a daughter. The words felt strange and foreign on my lips, but as I gazed at her, I felt a spark of something like hope ignite within me. Maybe, just maybe, this little girl would bring some sense of purpose into my life. Maybe she'd be the one to finally bring Tom and me together, to make us into the family we were supposed to be. I reached out a trembling hand and gently stroked her soft, downy hair. 'Hello, little one,' I whispered. 'Welcome to the world.'

en_results_raw: I had practically invited the remark by my own attitude, and I couldn't very well defend Gatsby without revealing the facts which I had kept so carefully to myself. I decided to give up the idea of going to his funeral, but as the day wore on I began to feel a strong desire to get away somewhere, to leave the city and its familiar faces behind me. I called up several people, trying to find someone who would go with me, but no one seemed to be free, and in the end I set off alone, driving through the rain-soaked streets to the railway station. The train was almost empty, and I found a compartment to myself, where I sat staring out of the window at the grey, blurred landscape. As we drew out of the city, the rain grew heavier, drumming against the roof of the carriage and sending little rivulets of water streaming down the windows. I felt a sense of relief wash over me as the city gave way to the suburbs, and the suburbs to the open countryside. I was glad to be leaving it all behind, to be getting away from the memories and the associations that haunted me. But as the train rumbled on, I couldn't shake off the feeling of unease that had settled over me. I kept thinking of Gatsby, and the strange, tragic figure he had cut in his final days. I thought of his grand, doomed dream, and the way it had ended in death and disillusionment. And I couldn't help but wonder what the future held, not just for me, but for all of us who had been caught up in the whirlwind of Gatsby's life.

en_results_raw: of bewildering railway journeys faded beyond the city's outlying wires, I was conscious that the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors' eyes was in some way changed, and that the white palaces of fashionable East Egg were not so white as they seemed, nor their bright lawns so green. The valley of ashes, too, seemed to have a different quality, a different feel, as if the very earth itself had been tainted by the moral decay that lay just beneath its surface. And as I sat there, brooding on the past, I couldn't help but wonder if the East would ever be the same again, or if the memories of Gatsby and all that he represented would forever be etched in my mind like a scar.

es_results_raw: chimeneas de las fábricas de Chicago se desvaneció, me sentí liberado de una pesadilla. El invierno siguiente, cuando vine a la ciudad para trabajar, me sentí más cerca de la realidad, más cerca de la vida real. Pero siempre recordaba a Gatsby, su sonrisa, su mirada, su forma de hablar. Y siempre recordaba el valle de cenizas, ese lugar desolado y triste que parecía simbolizar la decadencia y la corrupción de la sociedad. Me preguntaba qué habría sido de Daisy, de Tom, de Jordan, de todos los que habían estado envueltos en la vida de Gatsby. ¿Habrían encontrado la felicidad, la paz, la redención? ¿O seguirían atrapados en su mundo de superficialidad y vacuidad? Nunca lo sabría, pero sabía que yo había cambiado, que mi visión del mundo había cambiado para siempre después de conocer a Gatsby.

en_first_half: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent
en_second_half: sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
en_results: future to take care of them. So I went to the little office and asked to see the manager, a man named Mr. Jenkins, who had always been civil to me in a rather distant way. He looked up from the papers on
en_results_raw: future to take care of them. So I went to the little office and asked to see the manager, a man named Mr. Jenkins, who had always been civil to me in a rather distant way. He looked up from the papers on his desk as I entered, and I could see the faintest glimmer of curiosity in his eyes. I closed the door behind me and took a deep breath, trying to choose my words carefully. "Mr. Jenkins," I began, "I wanted to speak to you about my account. I've been thinking, and I've decided that I'd like to close it." He raised an eyebrow, clearly surprised, and I could sense a hint of disappointment behind his polite smile. "I see," he said slowly. "May I ask why?" I hesitated, unsure of how much to reveal, but something about his expression put me at ease. "To be honest, I'm not sure I'll be needing it anymore," I replied, trying to sound casual. Mr. Jenkins nodded thoughtfully, his eyes narrowing slightly as he processed this information. "I understand," he said finally. "We'll take care of it right away. Is there anything else I can help you with?" I shook my head, feeling a sense of relief wash over me. "No, that's all. Thank you, Mr. Jenkins." He nodded again, and I turned to leave, feeling a sense of closure, of loose ends being tied up. As I walked out of the office, I couldn't help but wonder what the future held, but for the first time in a long time, I felt a sense of hope, of possibility.
